citations.narrative:
Food receptacles are not being kept clean and sanitized. In the large, sheltered housing building the facility utilizes metal
gravity feeders as food receptacles for the dogs. In two primary enclosures currently housing a single English bulldog and
a single French bulldog the feeders were observed with an excessive buildup of thick brown food residue caked onto the
interior surfaces at the bottom of the feeders.
Food residue and organic material buildup can harbor microorganisms that can result in disease and health problems in
dogs. The facility must ensure that food receptacles are kept clean and sanitized in accordance with 3.11(b) and
measures must be taken to ensure that there is no molding, deterioration, and caking of feed.
Correct by 6 October 2025

The facility is not following the Program of Veterinary Care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for DAPP/Leptospirosis (7-way) at 10 weeks of age, 14 weeks of age, and annually
going forward. The Program of Veterinary Care also prescribes a rabies vaccine will be administered at 16 weeks of age,
booster at 1 year, and then every 3 years going forward.
3 adult dogs are not up to date on their DAPP/Lepto (7-way) vaccine:
- #9090 Daisy DOB 2/20/2025 received a DAPP vaccine on 4/10/2025 but has not received a 7-way vaccine.
- #9082 Patty DOB 2/8/2025 received a DAPP vaccine on 4/19/2025 but has not received a 7-way vaccine.
-#8161 Oscar DOB 12/16/24 received a DAPP/Lepto vaccine on 3/10/2025 at 12 weeks of age but did not receive an
additional dose of the vaccine at 14 weeks of age as required in the Program of Veterinary Care.
3 adult dogs have not received a rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age as required by the Program of Veterinary Care:
-# 9090 Daisy DOB 2/20/2025
-# 9082 Patty DOB 2/8/2025
-#8161 Oscar DOB 12/16/2024
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo,
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or
contagious diseases.
The facility is not following the Program of Veterinary Care for the prevention and treatment of heartworms. The Program
of Veterinary Care currently prescribes heartworm prevention will be administered monthly. The facility representative
states they do not currently administer monthly heartworm prevention to the dogs.
Failure to follow the preventative care plan for heartworm prevention in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule
can increase the risk of disease exposure and cause illness to the animals. The licensee must follow an appropriate
Program of Veterinary Care for dogs in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian for the
sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests.
Correct by 6 October 2025

The facility is not maintaining medical records for vaccinations. At the time of inspection, the facility was unable to provide
the APHIS inspector documentation of the rabies vaccine for two adult dogs Rose #7975 and Rita #2029. The APHIS
inspector was able to confirm with the AV that both dogs were up to date on the rabies vaccine.
Proper medical record documentation is a requirement of the Animal Welfare Act under §3.13(b). Failure to provide this
documentation prohibits the APHIS inspector’s ability to verify that the facility is following the Program of Veterinary Care
as prescribed by the Attending Veterinarian and to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care in a timely
and appropriate manner.
Dealers must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. The records
must include the information in the regulations under §3.13(b), including but not limited to the identity of the animal, the
names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration.
Correct by 6 October 2025 and going forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.9(b) 
   
Feeding 
Food receptacles are not being kept clean and sanitized. In the large, sheltered housing building the facility utilizes metal 
gravity feeders as food receptacles for the dogs. In two primary enclosures currently housing a single English bulldog and 
a single French bulldog the feeders were observed with an excessive buildup of thick brown food residue caked onto the 
interior surfaces at the bottom of the feeders.  
Food residue and organic material buildup can harbor microorganisms that can result in disease and health problems in 
dogs. The facility must ensure that food receptacles are kept clean and sanitized in accordance with 3.11(b) and 
measures must be taken to ensure that there is no molding, deterioration, and caking of feed. 
Correct by 6 October 2025 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the Program of Veterinary Care for vaccinations. The Program of Veterinary Care currently 
prescribes dogs will be vaccinated for DAPP/Leptospirosis (7-way) at 10 weeks of age, 14 weeks of age, and annually 
going forward. The Program of Veterinary Care also prescribes a rabies vaccine will be administered at 16 weeks of age, 
booster at 1 year, and then every 3 years going forward.  
 3 adult dogs are not up to date on their DAPP/Lepto (7-way) vaccine: 
- #9090 Daisy DOB 2/20/2025 received a DAPP vaccine on 4/10/2025 but has not received a 7-way vaccine.  
- #9082 Patty DOB 2/8/2025 received a DAPP vaccine on 4/19/2025 but has not received a 7-way vaccine. 
-#8161 Oscar DOB 12/16/24 received a DAPP/Lepto vaccine on 3/10/2025 at 12 weeks of age but did not receive an 
additional dose of the vaccine at 14 weeks of age as required in the Program of Veterinary Care.  
3 adult dogs have not received a rabies vaccine at 16 weeks of age as required by the Program of Veterinary Care: 
-# 9090 Daisy DOB 2/20/2025 
-# 9082 Patty DOB 2/8/2025 
-#8161 Oscar DOB 12/16/2024 
Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care does not ensure the 
dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as distemper, parvo, 
leptospirosis, and rabies which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination 
schedule approved by the attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or 
contagious diseases.

The facility is not following the Program of Veterinary Care for the prevention and treatment of heartworms. The Program 
of Veterinary Care currently prescribes heartworm prevention will be administered monthly. The facility representative 
states they do not currently administer monthly heartworm prevention to the dogs. 
Failure to follow the preventative care plan for heartworm prevention in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule 
can increase the risk of disease exposure and cause illness to the animals. The licensee must follow an appropriate 
Program of Veterinary Care for dogs in accordance with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian for the 
sampling and treatment of parasites and other pests. 
 
Correct by 6 October 2025 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not maintaining medical records for vaccinations. At the time of inspection, the facility was unable to provide 
the APHIS inspector documentation of the rabies vaccine for two adult dogs Rose #7975 and Rita #2029. The APHIS 
inspector was able to confirm with the AV that both dogs were up to date on the rabies vaccine.  
Proper medical record documentation is a requirement of the Animal Welfare Act under §3.13(b). Failure to provide this 
documentation prohibits the APHIS inspector’s ability to verify that the facility is following the Program of Veterinary Care 
as prescribed by the Attending Veterinarian and to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care in a timely 
and appropriate manner. 
Dealers must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS inspection. The records 
must include the information in the regulations under §3.13(b), including but not limited to the identity of the animal, the 
names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of administration.  
Correct by 6 October 2025 and going forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
